titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Rugh Family Papers
titlestmt.author: Martha Lund Smalley

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday March 26, 2019 at 22:15

did.unittitle: Rugh Family Papers
did.abstract: Correspondence and writings document the life and work of Dwight Rugh, his wife Winifred and their daughter Betty Jean during their service in China 1930-1951. The Rughs taught and did administrative work for the Yale-in-China Association at Yali Middle School, in Hunan Province. Winifred also taught at Shanghai American School, where Betty Jean attended for several years. Dwight Rugh was the last representative of the Yale-China Association to leave China in 1951, his application for an exit permit having been delayed for several months.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Rugh Family Papers (RG 244), Special Collections, Yale Divinity School Library

chronitem.event: Dwight Dekalb Rugh (DR) born in Clarion, Pennsylvania where his parents were teachers in Clarion Normal School

DR moved to California where his father was a school principal and later a professor of education a the University of California at Berkeley. The Rugh family, including DR's brother Charles and sister Winifred, lived in Los Gatos, CA where DR met his future wife, also named Winifred. She was the daughter of the town's Presbyterian minister.

DR received B.A. from University of California and went to Hawaii, where he started the student YMCA at the University of Hawaii. Winifred attended normal school and taught Kindergarten in California.
DR returned to California to marry Winifred (WR) and together they returned to Hawaii for three more years.
DR and WR moved to New Haven where he attended and graduated from Yale Divinity School.

DR and WR were invited to go to China by the Board of the Yale-in-China Association, which sponsored a middle school for boys and a teaching hospital in Changsha, Hunan. DR served as director of religious education and counseling while WR taught music.
Daughter Betty Jean born
Rugh family returned to New Haven where DR received a Ph.D. in religious education from Yale
Rugh family returned to China, with a stop in Hawaii, where DR was ordained as a Congregational minister

DR served as Mission Representative of Yale-in-China initially in Changsha and later in Yuanling, where the Yale-in-China school and hospital were evacuated to avoid Japanese troops entering Changsha.
Rugh family returned to the U.S.

After the war was over DR returned to China to resettle the Yale-in-China school and hospital in Changsha. WR and BJR joined him in 1946, BJR attending Shanghai American School 1947-1949 until evacuated when the Communists entered Shanghai. WR and BJR returned to the U.S.

DR remained in Changsha after the Communist army arrived. As the months passed it became more difficult for him to associate with his friends and to help with the affairs of the school. He was isolated in two rooms of his home and spent time playing his cello, writing poetry, reading, and writing long, frequent letters to WR and BJR. DR was under surveillance and subject to frequent questioning, with demands that he confess to being an American spy. In 1951 the school gymnasium, which was being rebuilt with Yale-in-China funds, was completed and shortly after DR was put on trial and sentenced to be deported. He was taken to Canton and put in prison but after a few days was brought to the border where he could walk to Hong Kong.
Following a year of rest in the U.S. DR becamse Dean of Men at the College of Idaho
DR accepted position as Assistant Director for the Federal Point Four Aid program to Israel and DR and WR lived in Israel
DR and WR went to Taiwan where DR was International Secretary for the YMCA in Taipei
The Rughs went to California to retire but later in the year joined VISTA, going to Norfolk, Virginia where WR trained teachers for the Headstart program and DR trained community workers.
Afer another brief period of retirement the Rughs rejoined VISTA and lived at Mammoth Cave National Park where they taught inner city youth in the Job Corps
DR and WR moved to Bristol Village to live nearer Betty Jean, who was now married to David Elder. They continued their educational work in various capacities.
DR died

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These papers provide valuable insight on the work of Dwight and Winifred Rugh with the Yale-in-China Association in Hunan province from 1931 to 1951. Frequent detailed letters to family and friends document the upheaval experienced due to the Sino-Japanese War and Communist takeover.

The Rugh Family Papers complement the archives of the Yale-China Association that are held at Yale's Sterling Memorial Library Manuscripts and Archives. Dwight Rugh's official staff correspondence and various motion picture films taken by Rugh are in the Yale-China Association Records. The Rugh Family Papers provide perspective on the family and personal life of the Rughs but also describe their daily work in Changsha and Yuanling. Letters of Betty Jean Rugh from her time at Shanghai American School complement the Shanghai American School archives found in Yale Divinity School Library Record Group no. 132.

did.unittitle: Correspondence
To extended family in U.S.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These letters are written by Dwight and Winifred Rugh primarily to "Dear Ones", to Dwight's sister Winifred and her husband Elgin, to "Father", "Aunt May and Gordon"

did.unittitle: Dwight (DR) and Winifred (WR) studying at North China Language School in Peiping [Beijing]; descriptions of daily life and activities; First Peoples' Convention of the Republic of China held in Beijing
Move to Shanghai; preparations for and move to Changsha; teaching at Yali Middle School
Incl. re. visit of Chiang Kai Shek to Yali campus; political conditions disruptive
Betty Jean (BJR) Rugh born March 12, 1933; family goes to Kuling for summer; 309 students at school

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: WR and BJR visited California during this period, due to the death of Winifred's father, then returned to China. There is a gap in letters home while the Rughs were in New Haven, CT on furlough 1935-1936, where Dwight earned a Ph.D. from Yale.

did.unittitle: Return to China following furlough with stop in Honolulu where DR was ordained; to Kuling during summer; Japan attacks on China lead to evacuations of missionaries

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Rughs were evacuated to Honolulu; DR returned to China in July 1937 while WR and BJR went to California where WR attended university. Yali Middle School moved to Yuanling. Upon return to China in 1940, WR and BJR went to Shanghai American School where WR taught and then to Yuanling in December 1940.

did.unittitle: At Yuanling and summer house in Shih Ch'iao; DR and WR teaching at Yali Middle School
Family in New Haven for furlough then DR returned to China and WR and BJR first to California and then China
Summer at Nan Yo then return to Changsha; WR and BJR to Shanghai American School; DR treasurer of International Hunan Relief Committee
DR to Hong Kong on business; WR evacuated to Shanghai, where she taught kindergarten at Shanghai American School
WR back in Changsha; soldiers around, uneasy feeling; WR and BJR return to US in 1949; DR remains in Changsha
DR alone in Changsha
To friends, the Smith sisters, in U.S.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These letters were written by Winifred Rugh to Ruth and Edith Smith of North Haven, CT, who are addressed as "Dear Two" or "Dear Ones"

Trip to Yuanling; teaching activities; bombings in nearby cities
Family in California; DR returns to Shanghai first and then WR and BJR return and are at Shanghai American School

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These letters were written by Dwight to his wife when they were separated; some are addressed to both Winifred and Betty Jean. Dwight and Winifred referred to themselves as "De" and "Fe".

did.unittitle: DR to WR from Honolulu before marriage; while WR is in California at the time of her father's death, while WR and BJR are in Kuling
